prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Requested sensitivity:
As detailed in the Science Case, we request the continuum sensitivity of 0.05 mJy at band 7. This corresponds to ~55 min of integration time per source (depending on the declination) and a total ~4.4 hr for 4 sources including calibration. This was calculated with the OT assuming an average weather condition of precipitable water vapour of 0.658 - 1.262 mm (2nd - 4th octile, depending on declination).
For the spectral window with the CO line this will result in the rms of 0.8 mJy per 10 km/s channels, so we will be able to detect the line if the star-forming region is similar to the WR region in the GRB 980425 host, based on our ALMA data for that object (Michalowski et al., in prep).
Imaging requirements:
We want to detect and localise star-forming regions in the GRB hosts at z<0.5, so we opt for the most extended configuration, with the resolution of 0.12-0.14". They will be point sources at this resolution, so the consideration of the maximum resolvable scale is not necessary for our science goals. We do not aim at detecting the overall smooth emission of the entire target galaxies.
Correlator setup:
We have chosen the band 7 as it gives the best infrared luminosity limit for a given integration time compared to other bands. It still probes the dust emission (unlike lower frequency bands), but is not so weather dependant as band 8 and 9. As an additional goal of the proposal we tuned one spectral window to the frequency of the CO(3-2) or CO(4-3) line.
In order to achieve the best possible sensitivity we will use the dual polarisation mode. We selected the Frequency Division Mode for the spectral window tracing the CO line. This will result in the spectral resolution of ~ 1 km/s, so we may need to bin the spectrum to obtain a significant signal, as the expected line width is of the order of a few tens km/s. However, we note that detecting this line is not the main aim of this proposal. For other spectral windows we selected the Time Division Mode to limit the data rate.
Calibration: Default
Bandpass accuracy: Standard
Scheduling/time constraints: None
Data rate: Normal
Special constraints on standard observing modes: The proposed targets are GRB hosts, which are spread uniformly on the sky, so in the most of the cases it was not possible to find any other suitable target within <10 deg. This results in significant overheads, but this is the only way to observe these unique extragalactic objects, which were not selected from deep fields (similarly to high-z quasars).
As in the first Science Goal.
As in the first Science Goal.
As in the first Science Goal.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Long gamma-ray bursts are bright explosions signaling the death of short lived massive stars. Thus, we would expect GRBs to trace the brightest star-forming regions in their host galaxies. However, our recent Herschel observations of the closest GRB host galaxy (980425) showed that the far-IR is dominated by a star-forming region 800pc away from the GRB explosion site, suggesting that the GRB progenitor was a runaway star. We propose to use the unequaled resolution and sensitivity of ALMA/band 7 in extended configuration to localize star-forming regions in the host galaxies of 4 well-chosen GRBs, and constrain their star formation rate and the dust and gas content. We wish to answer the following questions: i) are sub-mm bright star-forming regions always present at the GRB site and what are their features? ii) if not, is a sub-mm bright star-forming region very close the GRB position, supporting the hypothesis that GRB-progenitors are runaway stars? iii) or, are there no bright star-forming regions close enough the explosion site? The answers to these questions will have strong implications on whether long GRBs are good tracers of star formation.
